TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesdays: The "Notice My Bug Report, Senpai" Edition

Articles.Content:
<p><img src="https://31.media.tumblr.com/0ff9377afa68dc3ad3fe6844aaf1bd38/tumblr_inline_nbnrj76Shf1rr2wit.jpg"/></p>

<p><strong>Felipe (HarvesteR)</strong><span><strong>:</strong> Last week was the first week of QA. A number of features have already been integrated into the main development branch and tested. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve also taken some time to upgrade and overhaul our issue tracker, to add an issue voting system and a complete revision of the styling rules to make the more important issues more visible at a glance. This has already proven worthwhile as several issues we would have probably dismissed as being of lesser importance have surfaced with high vote counts, which indicates that even though a bug/feature request/feedback item may be technically of low severity, subjectively, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s seen as very relevant. </span></p>

<p><span>This week, we are setting up the Administration Facility systems to be QA tested, and IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m having a go here at a little app to help maintain the issue tracker in a serviceable state. The number of old builds has been piling up, and we need something to help us manage them.</span></p>

<p><strong>Alex (aLeXmOrA): </strong><span>Last week I had intended to continue with the changes to the KSP Store website. However, since an office remodeling is going on here at Squad HQ, the main routers that provide the office with internet needed to be moved from where they were and that left us without internet access for a day. I helped Jesus change cables and connect the network devices to restore the signal and make sure everyone at the office can access the web. Now, with everything working as it should, I can go on with the website tweaks.</span></p>

<p><strong>Mike (Mu):</strong><span> IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve spent some time implementing the new parts from PorkJet and some upgrades for our old parts from Hugo. To get the new cargo bays to work properly IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve slightly reworked the ModuleAnimateGeneric to enable it to toggle whilst animating and also to enable access from EVA. Apart from all that iÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been assisting the team in implementing and testing the 0.25 features and also tinkering with some interesting new developments for 0.26. Stay tuned. </span></p>

<p><span><strong>Marco (Samssonart):</strong> </span><span>Basically wrapping up my share of QA and on standby for Experimentals. The most puzzling bug that happened during QA was a Unity bug thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s also present in 0.24 - the crew hatch menu doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t work on mac. <del>After some tinkering I figured out itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a bug that got fixed with Unity 4.5.3. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re still waiting for confirmation on that one, but all points to it being fixed, which is good news all around for mac users.</del>Turns out it wasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t. Back to the drawing board!</span></p>

<p><span>While that happens I updated the info of the orbiting tutorials to include the newly implemented navball vectors and IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m going through some old an undocumented code to find out how to implement said vectors for the IVA navball as well, fun times.</span></p>

<p><strong>Daniel (danRosas)</strong><span><strong>:</strong> Finished the Administration Building backdrop, to have it more than ready for the upcoming release. According to the position of the building in the Space Center, you should be able to see the VAB and the Astronaut Complex. Since I like going more into the properties of a telephoto lens, the objects in the image may appear closer than they are in real life. .Since itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s still a WIP feature, this could change in the close future. You can have a look of it <a href="http://i.imgur.com/61IYauk.jpg"><strong>HERE</strong></a>. </span><span></span></p>

<p><span>On other matters, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re moving ahead on the assets weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re getting ready. The communication channel goes from us artists (Roy, Nick and I) to Miguel, Felipe, and so forth. In order to have a clear scope of whatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s intended. Next week I want to start doing tests in Unity, in order to have a closer approach of how those assets are going to look like inside the game.</span></p>

<p><strong>Jim (Romfarer)</strong><span><strong>:</strong> ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s time to do some maintenance on GUI atlases and prefabs. In case you didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know: an atlas is a texture with many smaller textures baked into it. The main benefit of doing this is to reduce the amount of memory used by the GUI. A prefab is basically a gameobject template used to instantiate multiple gameobjects which share the same behavior. We use those for all EzGUIÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s in the game because itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s easier to manage scenes and atlas updates.</span></p>

<p><span>Over time, many of the GUI prefabs have received small updates and as a result the amount of atlases used in many of them have grown. So what IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m doing this week is re-building the atlases in order to reduce the amount of atlases in use per prefab in an effort to have as few atlases as possible in use at any point.</span></p>

<p><span><strong>Max (Maxmaps):</strong> </span><span>IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been working closely with the art team to get the giant 0.26 project done in time. Which has proven to have a bit of an extra challenge to it due to the fact that we need the art team for a couple more things in 0.25, related to the admin building and what have you.</span></p>

<p><span>WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve pulled it off however, and hope you will have your fingers on this update sooner than youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d expect.</span></p>

<p><strong>Bob (Calisker):</strong><span> I worked with a newspaper reporter who was interested in </span><span>Kerbal Space Program</span><span> as a game to include in a feature about what games kids will be playing after Minecraft. Hopefully, </span><span>KSP </span><span>makes the list! We also had an interesting discussion with Charlie Hall from </span><span>Polygon</span><span>, who caught glimpse of Scott ManleyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s challenge to players to get into orbit and back to Kerbin in under 3 minutes. Charlie posted this </span><strong><a href="http://goo.gl/FtTtGf">STORY</a></strong><span>, which included some talk about planned changes to our atmosphere. It was a tricky question because itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s something still being discussed but we donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t have a concrete answer at this time. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s one of the toughest parts about being a communications person for a game in Early Access. Sometimes it feels weird to say, Ã¢â‚¬Å“we donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know,Ã¢â‚¬Â even when itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the most honest answer. </span></p>

<p><span>One more thing, I have a question for everybody! Did you download and play our demo before buying the game? Please answer <a href="http://goo.gl/mx72KE"><strong>HERE</strong></a></span><span>. </span></p>

<p><strong>Ted (Ted):</strong><span> My week has been filled with mostly miscellaneous QA management tasks; keeping documentation on our features current, looking for ways to improve our bug tracking system and implementing them (though Felipe implements the Ã¢â‚¬ËœmeatierÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ ones), the list goes on. One of the many tasks has been assisting the QA Testers with the testing on the Ã¢â‚¬Ëœsecret featureÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ and the features Marco had been working on (Navball improvement, crew transfer and vessel markers in the KSC). Our Linux QA Tester sal_vager goes into detail on how that went for him this week:</span></p>

<p><span><strong>sal_vager [Linux QA Team]:</strong> <em>I collaborated with the other QA members to confirm issues that had been found, as well as finding a few myself, the most notable being a regression issue with the recovery of Kerbals that was speedily fixed by the devs.</em></span></p>

<p><em>Also, I worked with TriggerAu (Windows QA Team) specifically on issue 2946 (title would give away the secret feature), it was a deep issue with many aspects that needed to be checked, between us we were able to test all the conditions set out by Felipe.</em></p>

<p><em>So far the Linux version hasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t thrown up any platform specific bugs yet thankfully, even in the 64bit version.</em></p>

<p><span>Moving on, while we havenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t been actively testing new content in Experimentals, that hasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t stopped the Experimental Testers from keeping busy. One of the new Experimental Testers for Windows sums up what theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been up to below:</span></p>

<p><strong>Steve (Squelch) [Windows Experimental Team]: </strong><em>As one of the new Experimental Testers, this past week has been my first full week on the team! What has that involved? Well, for a start it involved mixing with some really interesting and intelligent people all with a common goal - making KSP better! After a wonderfully warm welcome, it was time to get down to our duties as Experimental Testers. I quickly got to grips with the KSP Bug Tracker, which uses Redmine a project management web app IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve had experience with before.</em></p>

<p><em>Myself and a couple of the other testers took it upon ourselves to review the outstanding tickets, as itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a relatively quiet period apparently - 0.24.2 is out in the wild. This involves interpreting what the reporter is trying to tell us. This is a mixed bag that can vary from reports from experienced software engineers, to novice Ã¢â‚¬Å“I want to report a bugÃ¢â‚¬Â type affairs. All of them are important and all of them need attention. </em></p>

<p><em>We discuss what the causes in these reports might be, what the workarounds are, and what impact they might have on the playability of the game, as well as the system as a whole. Once we have confirmed the report as valid - and that takes much deliberation in some cases - we copy the report to the internal tracker for Developer attention. In essence, testers act as triage, to use a medical term, where we direct attention of the Developers and Quality Assurance (QA) team to particular problems the players of KSP are having.</em></p>

<p><em>Thankfully, it is all done with excellent humour, and draws upon a diverse skill-set with the testers. What better benefits could one wish for? Insight and laughs have made for a great week.</em></p>

<p><span><strong>Anthony (Rowsdower):</strong> IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been busy doing the usual amount of monitoring around the community. I recently dumped a big manifesto on the KSP-TV crew for where IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d like to take the channel. All good things with time, of course. Where would you like to see it go? What things would you like to see on there? Other than some really obvious choices, of course IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m also coming up with ideas for a contest next month. The prizes are all set, but IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m still filling in the blanks on the action part of it haha. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Halloween time. Perhaps that can be of use. Any suggestions? max also let me have a look at <a href="http://i.imgur.com/xQQVl7s.png"><strong>SOME PIC</strong></a> before. It looked radÃ¢â‚¬Â¦oh wait. Crap, I wasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t supposed to show that, was I? Oh well. 50 lashes to the community manager.<br/></span></p>

<p><strong>Rogelio (Roger):</strong><span> IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been fixing some of the models IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been doing during these past weeks. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m trying to reduce the polycount without losing quality so the textures need to be fixed as well. I like how stuff is getting done. Dan, Max and I have been working together to finish on time without quitting sleep hours. Believe me weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re doing some cool stuff.</span></p>

Edited September 10, 2014 by Rowsdower

Any chance of having ModuleAnimateGeneric support VAB toggling and sounds? Add those two, and Firespitter-based animations could get some rest. I'm really looking forward to 0.25, it looks like some long-awaited fixes and modifications are going to be in. That's gonna make life a lot easier for modders.

Good notes, and before wednesday as well.

On that pic that Rowsdower leaked, is the grass color different? Love the bomb bay.

Rowsdower has revealed the location of the Admin Building

Also, yay! Bomb bays! Woohoo- I mean, inverted bays for volatile cargo deployment! Woohoo!

Any chance of having ModuleAnimateGeneric support VAB toggling and sounds? Add those two, and Firespitter-based animations could get some rest. I'm really looking forward to 0.25, it looks like some long-awaited fixes and modifications are going to be in. That's gonna make life a lot easier for modders.

Agreed, having AnimateGeneric be tweakable in VAB would be just swell. Would be surprised if EVA tweaking comes without that, though.
Good devnotes again.
Are you guys working on fixing 64-bit stability at all? Or is that something you have to wait for Unity to fix?
Since other Win-x64 Unity apps don't suffer the exception CTDing, even if it is a Unity issue it's one Squad can work around.

Love that title.

Great notes, lots of sneak peeks, lots of info, lots of fun!

Also, lots of Hype, with continued mention of a "secret feature"

Oh, joy! The OS X crew hatch bug from 0.18 has returned! Hope you can get it ironed out, having it return 7 versions later means it's a particularly nasty little bug...

I like the Administration building backsplash, very SpaceX-like.

New parts look great, but as has been stated before, giving ModuleAnimateGeneric the ability to be toggled in the VAB/SPH would make using the cargo bays loads easier.

I actually suck enough that I can't tell from the two pics where the admin building would be.

Nice. Answered poll. I've already sent a few buddies to get the demo as well.

Oh yeah, I know about that. It's so crazy how REDACTED REDACTED REDACTED and REDACTED REDACTED REDACTED combine to make this awesome REDACTED REDACTED REDACTED. It makes the game so much better.
All I know is, I'm desperate to move my office to the Administration Building now.
